comments.commentBody:
I'm sure that lots of people around the world who are genuinely oppressed because of their religion - no matter which one - would be happy to trade places with the plaintiffs who brought this ridiculous lawsuit.

Victims of religious persecution through the ages must be laughing in their graves at the idea that the Little Sisters of the Poor consider themselves oppressed.
The clue for 35A is a bit of a stretch.  Baseball season does start in April and the DC team is the NATIONALS, so the Post might right about them.  Does that REALLY make a NAT a "figure" in the Post?

What strikes me about this article (and this discussion) is how so many of us are so embarrassed about our basic bodily functions (not to mention sexual functions.)

When I was younger, I was too. I know I've become more casual about my body and it helps that Asian people seem rather more casual than Americans in general.

Is there something here we can learn from the Asians?

Four of us had the bottle of La Gravitate de Certan during a meal of rewarmed fried chicken and sides. At the beginning of the meal, one of our party indicated that the nose on the wine was like the essence of good fruit. Later, as the meal progressed, another expressed how much he enjoyed the mouthfeel of the wine, describing how the tannins melted in one's mouth and seemed to seep deep into the tongue, coming back to life for a long lingering finish on every taste bud. Finally, at the end of the meal, we all agreed that the nose and taste of the wine seemed to grow in stature. It soldiered on and on. We look forward to trying more Pomerol wines in the near future.
Too many people think that everybody should believe what they believe.  It's a my way or the highway kind of world. People complain of religious intolerance.  Secular intolerance is no better.
One can develop any make-believe and claim it's a religion, then get a tax exemption.  Millions in profiteering and crystal cathedrals anyone?  Laughing all the way to the bank!

The US needs more Protestants on SCOTUS. Germany has had similar problems with the opinions of Adenauer and his followers. With the reunification this has faded away. The East Germans are much more open to equality for women.
It's just the way health insurance works.  It's no different from sharing the cost of your bypass surgery.

Yes it can be health care. My mother had 8 pregnancies resulting in 7 children and became ill after the last pregnancy. Her body was spent. Her doctor told her if she got pregnant again she would die. So my mother sought guidance from our (horrible) parish priest who said, "No Birth Control!" And yet, Catholic wives are supposed to be available for sex when ever the husband wants it. Go figure that one out! I told her that the world is not black and white like the parish priest seemed to think. It is gray and God gave us brains for a reason. He doesn't expect you to die and leave behind a husband and 7 children nor does he expect you to go without conjugal bliss. She went on birth control and is now 82, thank you very much! 'The Pill' is prescribed for many health related reasons, not just birth control (which I personally believe IS health care).

Actually Birth control IS healthcare. You are misinformed.  Many women need it for various medical reasons, as well as for being responsible about their lives.  Please get educated about this. Ignorance such as this is destructive.

The United States of America is one of the very few countries in the free world which continues to control women's bodies.  For all the spouting the politicians do about "freedom" and "democracy" and "rights", women remain left behind in USA.
Let the churches start paying taxes before they assert their "rights."
So women end up with a separate but equal insurance card for contraceptive coverage - what’s not to like?

Why don't we just get it over with and have a statute that lets people excuse themselves from any law with which they have a religious disagreement? Then we can have the theocratic system that Republicans seem to want.

No, what they are trying to do is penalize women who do not accept THEIR belief that contraception is immoral.  By refusing to participate in a program that allows their employees, whatever their own religion might be, freedom of choice and freedom to follow their own conscience, they are saying that women who choose to use contraceptives in violation of the beliefs of the Little Sisters will be punished by having to purchase contraception out of their own, perhaps limited, funds or do without no matter the consequences.  Whatever happened to their loving God?

Mr. Case, sir, the government isn't trying to force the poor little set upon church to pay for mortal sins.

They are asking them to fill out a form, which takes them off the hook for paying for mortal sins.

What about this don't you understand?

That was my first reaction to Alito's outlandish statement as well.  Isn't this provision exactly what he said was appropriate in the Hobby Lobby case?  Perhaps Adam Liptak could file another story on how exactly the provision under consideration here differs from what Justice Alito was seeking?

The nuns pay for it by having it taken from their paycheck but they are not paying out of pocket? What a liberal mindset you show. Even if the government picked up the tab we are still paying out of pocket. It's called taxes. But back to the point, just because it's taken before we can cash the check it is still out of pocket.

I simply cannot understand how allowing women access to birth control under their health insurance policy could somehow be considered a "moral wrong." Forcing women (especially impoverished young women) to bring unwanted lives into the world, when they are not emotionally or financially prepared to do so, seems like a much greater "moral wrong" to me. Not to mention that once you become a public employer, you should not be allowed to allow your religious views to block proper healthcare options for the people you employ.
But is seems religion is always given a "green light" to not pay taxes or cooperate in many other ways in American society.

How is it possible anyone can still be asking such a ridiculous question? Do you object when a man carrying the same insurance policy as yourself has his Cialis covered? Do you object when a fellow policyholder who is obese required diabetes care? Do you object when a fellow policyholder's dependent child requires nebulizer treatment? Do you nitpick over everyone else's minute healthcare details and obsess over which ones you deem worthy of the coverage your common insurance provides, and which ones you object to paying?
One might argue that every insurance payout is a form of coercion, except for the highly relevant fact that the very nature of insurance is a shared pool in which ALL are covered - whether they are women seeking contraception, men with ED, elderly persons on dementia medications, children with ADHD....the list is endless.
"Fairness" is a fairly irrelevant term to apply to insurance - and to health, for that matter. It isn't "fair" that someone can pay into insurance but never need it for more than an annual checkup. It isn't "fair" that a non smoker should get lung cancer. It isn't "fair" that drug prices increase so much, so rapidly.
If "fairness" is what one seeks in insurance, well - those people must find life terribly difficult to navigate. Unfairness everywhere!
Alito may be one of the most stupid people ever appointed to the Supreme Court.
Especially when you consider how the government pressured the Mormons to renounce polygamy.

Indeed, Mr Alito is rabidly political and opposed to women's freedoms all his life. Even as a member of his Princeton Univ. eating club he opposed women members.  Including fellow Princeton students such as Justice Sotomayor!
Alito's comment that the "government's approach represented "an unprecedented threat to religious liberty in this country" strikes me as one of the stupidest things I have ever heard.

Birth Control isn't prescribed ONLY to prevent conception, but rather for a variety of symptoms and diseases, including but not limited to: PMDD, endometriosis, and vertigo, which is the reason I take it. Some people will still be able to afford Birth Control without insurance, but many won't. For those that cannot afford it, this is the first step in a very dangerous spiral down to back alley abortions. If a woman cannot protect her ability to choose when or if she wants a child, and becomes pregnant, that same woman will undoubtedly run into serious problems with all of the new/recent TRAP laws. She'll have difficulty getting to a clinic that performs abortions, if there's one near her, and those TRAP laws will make her go through days or weeks of red tape. Until, of course, it's too late for a first trimester abortion, which is the purpose of the laws in the first place. Delay, delay, delay. She might be tempted by a back alley abortion, and she may not survive. But do the justices think about the future "her"? I imagine that they don't.

Most of those organizations that you mentioned did receive an exemption from the government. This suit is about filing a form. A form! The form registers their objection, so the insurance company handles it. So, what else can be done? This is ridiculous.
Those employees pay for their benefits. It's not free.

Doesn't it all just come down to: "Whose plan is it, anyway?" The conservative Justices seem to think the insurance policy is the school's or hospital's or nursing home's plan. But isn't it really the insurance company's plan to begin with, which the employer provides as part of the employee's compensation package? If so, how is it being "hijacked" from the employer. If the employer was an ordinary for-profit business corporation, it would receive a tax deduction for it's cost as a business expense: the the company doesn't buy it for itself, it buys the plan for its employees. Sounds like the insurance belongs to the employees. Whether for or non-profit, the employer could easily
provide a "flex-benefit" cash payment to each employee to buy insurance directly and thus not be taxed on the amount
-- would that cash payment somehow implicate the church-related proprietors in how the employee used that cash? There is no stateable limit to that sort of exception, unless we want to say religiously affiliated employers now must be exempted from the minimum wage or paying any wages at all given that the employees might do something sinful with that money.
